title: Arizona's Water Systems
subtitle: An interactive story of the Salt River Project and the Central Arizona Project.
footer:
This story is based on presentations and information from:
Jacob Richardson, Salt River Project
Brian Buzard, Central Arizona Project
Ryan Johnson, Central Arizona Water Conservation District
Tom Buschatzke, Arizona Department of Water Resources (ADWR)

Salt River Project (SRP) | Central Arizona Project (CAP)

chapters.title: Central Arizona Project: A Lifeline from the Colorado
chapters.description: The Central Arizona Project (CAP) is a 336-mile aqueduct that brings water from the Colorado River to Central and Southern Arizona. Its delivery amounts depend heavily on the river's health and water levels, which vary year to year based on snowpack and drought conditions. See the full system map here.

chapters.title: The CAP Canal System
chapters.description: From Lake Havasu, a series of massive pumping plants lift the water over 2,900 feet in elevation, allowing it to flow south through a network of canals, tunnels, and siphons to serve millions of people and vast agricultural lands.

chapters.title: The Salt River Project
chapters.description: The Salt River Project (SRP) manages a different watershed, primarily the Salt and Verde Rivers. It operates a series of dams and reservoirs that provide a surface water supply to the Phoenix metropolitan area. Learn more about SRP.

chapters.title: The Verde River Dams
chapters.description: The Verde River system, a major tributary to the Salt, is managed by two dams. We begin with the most upstream reservoir.

chapters.title: 1. Horseshoe Dam (Verde River)
chapters.description: Horseshoe Dam, the most upstream dam on the Verde River, was completed in 1946. It serves primarily as a storage reservoir to capture runoff.

chapters.title: 2. Bartlett Dam (Verde River)
chapters.description: Downstream is Bartlett Dam, which forms Bartlett Reservoir. Completed in 1939, its construction predates Horseshoe, and it was the world's highest multiple-arch dam at the time.

chapters.title: The Salt River Dams
chapters.description: The main branch of the SRP system is the Salt River itself, controlled by a staircase of four major dams that provide critical water storage and hydroelectric power.

chapters.title: 1. Theodore Roosevelt Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: The system's cornerstone, Roosevelt Dam (1911), is the most upstream and forms the largest reservoir, providing the primary water storage for the river.

chapters.title: 2. Horse Mesa Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: Downstream from Roosevelt, Horse Mesa Dam (1927) forms Apache Lake and is a key power generator.

chapters.title: 3. Mormon Flat Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: Next, Mormon Flat Dam (1925) creates Canyon Lake and features powerful pumped-storage hydro capabilities.

chapters.title: 4. Stewart Mountain Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: The final dam, Stewart Mountain Dam (1930), forms Saguaro Lake before releasing water into the valley's canal system.

chapters.title: The Governing Agencies
chapters.description: Managing this complex system involves multiple key agencies. The Arizona Department of Water Resources (ADWR) oversees water rights and long-term planning, while the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) ensures water quality standards are met. Many of these projects were originally funded and constructed by the federal Bureau of Reclamation, which still plays a role in the region.
